The CDSA offers end-to-end development

With VR, we can do a much deeper

So, I'm going to introduce one of our

Um, Artemis is NASA's program to send
humans back to the moon and eventually
on the Mars. The lunar gateway has been
in the works since 2017 as a modular
space station that will orbit the moon
and serve as a staging point for human
and robotic missions to the surface.
It's not meant to be permanently crude
like the International Space Station,
but astronauts will visit it during
Artemis Artemis missions. It's an
international effort. Modules and craft
are being designed and assembled by
multiple companies and space agencies
across the world. We built a complete
simulation of the fully assembled
gateway showcasing its modular modular
design and how it evolves across
missions. Each module is built as a
standalone blueprint and any
interactable actors such as stowage or
equipment are are set up inside as child
actors. The structure allows us to move
entire modules with a push of a button
and lets us test different
configurations on the fly.
So obviously with microgravity movements
we need to simulate microgravity
movement to some extent or with
microgravity environments we need to
simulate microgravity movement. So with
so many people coming in with varying
degrees of experience with VR, we had to
create something that was somewhat
beginner friendly. The user sits in a
swivel chair with their feet up. So that
gives them at least 100 360 degree
freedom of movement. Um and so moving
inside microgravity environment is
called translating. And to do this in
our projects, the user will stick out
their hand on a surface, use the grab
button to grab the surface, and then
pull or push themselves and let go. It's
physics based, so they'll continue
flying in that direction and bounce off
walls till they steady themselves by
grabbing another surface. So, you can
imagine how that might make some people
sick. So, we also have a fly button
which enables them to push a thumb stick
and move in any direction they want. And
when they let go, they'll come to a
complete stop.
So, we found giving them the option to
rotate smoothly in a non 90° axis was a
recipe for motion sickness. So, as a
general rule, we just don't let players
rotate themselves besides physically
moving in a circle on the chair. Uh, we
can press keys that rotate rotate them
along a 90 degree axis if needed. This
is important since there's no um
definitive up in space and we need to
test different orientations of the
spacecraft.
We also have the ability to add tractors
to the feet and the elbows if we're
doing a more more involved volutric
analysis. This also has the added
benefit of allowing them to use their
feet to anchor themselves in place. Much
like using the hand to grab the surface,
you can grab your feet, use your feet to
grab the surface. This is something that
real astronauts do more often in zero
gravity because by using their feet to
steady themselves, it keeps their hands
free for whatever task they're working
on.

uh materials are usually created with

minimum residency incrementally until it

to fix issues such as curved objects

looking mesh.
Collision is an issue as well since we

uh when it makes sense, when it's

as a custom complex collision.
So we use lumen and IEES profiles to
accurately depict lighting while still
being performant in VR. An IEES profile
stands for illuminating engineering
society profile and is a data file
format used to accurately describe the
light distribution characteristics of a
specific light source. Realistic
lighting in VR is important for
spacecraft design. It creates an
immersive environment that helps
visualize how the spacecraft will
function under real world conditions,
including emergencies or varying light
levels in space. Prior to 5.5, we could
have around six to eight lights with an
area of a 10 meter radius of the player.
If we set the fade out distance of those
lights to,200
um anymore and we would get performance
concerns. You could see how that
wouldn't be ideal because if you get
more than 1200 units away, the light
will callull itself. Um but within the
area of one module, we could get pretty
accurate lighting. Um, but we just
recently switched to 5.5, upgraded to
5.5 and turn on mega lights and turn off
the fade out distance. Um, so all the
lights are visible all the time and even
with hardware ray tracing turned on,
which is needed for megalytes. We only
saw um a minor decrease in performance.
We're still testing this and evaluating
if the lighting is still as accurate
using megalytes, but so far it's looking
really good and we're quite happy.
So when it comes to human space flight,
managing limited space and translation
paths is a challenge, especially in the

narrower interior than the International
Space Station.
In order to test translation paths and

different tasks. We can also change the

99% to a 50% to a 1% male or female,
which means we're able to test the
volume of the space with the largest and
smallest possible body types.

Fidelity versus usability. In some

So when we design for space flight,

that's quite powerful. Using Unreal
